Award.AwardTitle: An Integrated Series of Student-driven, Research-based Undergraduate Laboratory Courses Linking Chemical Biology, Biochemistry, and Neurobiology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Curricular changes link three distinct scientific disciplines (chemical biology, biochemistry, and neurobiology) through the introduction of a series of three thematically-connected, research-based laboratories. In these discipline courses, students synthesize novel biological imaging agents (chemical biology), using these same imaging agents to catalogue the substrate specificity of ester hydrolases from Mycobacterium tuberculosis (TB) (biochemistry), and combine the products to screen for new components of neural signaling in Caenorhabditis elegans (neurobiology). The introduction of open-ended, hypothesis-driven research design into three biomolecular science laboratories increases student exposure to the practice of scientific research. Students practice the skills necessary to be working scientists, including formulating hypotheses, designing experimental plans, solving problems, and communicating results both orally and in writing. In addition, students organize a symposium at a regional undergraduate research conference. Students in these courses are challenged to integrate multiple scientific disciplines and a diverse set of laboratory skills within the context of larger scientific investigations (TB infection and neuronal communication). Student participation in projects allows them to contribute new knowledge and research tools to the understanding of the biochemistry of TB infection and neuronal communication. Overall, the three linked courses introduce students to interdisciplinary science, allowing students to participate in current areas of research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Course-based undergraduate research laboratories (CUREs) have gained significant traction as alternatives to traditional laboratory courses. Spurred by calls for STEM laboratory reform across presidential and other influential national scientific panels, CUREs provide students from diverse populations access to the measurable benefits of undergraduate research experiences (UREs) while balancing faculty, student, and institutional roadblocks to involvement in UREs. Through funding from the NSF, we have implemented and assessed three pedagogically and thematically linked CUREs spanning chemical biology, biochemistry, and neurobiology. These courses engaged students in novel scientific research questions of broad societal importance involving the development and use of fluorescent detection tools to investigate diverse aspects of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection or neural signaling and produced significant publishable and presentable research outcomes. In the chemical biology laboratory, students designed, synthesized, and chemically characterized the properties of a novel library of fluorogenic substrates. For the biochemistry laboratory, students worked together to understand the structure, function, and biological relevance of novel enzymes from M. tuberculosis, using the fluorogenic substrates from the chemical biology course. In the neurobiology laboratory, students used fluorescence imaging and RNA interference to identify and begin to characterize genes with novel roles in controlling neural synapse structure. Although inherent chemical properties of the fluorogenic substrates prevented their incorporation into the neurobiology course, this initial drawback was taken as a scientific challenge that led to ongoing, collaborative scientific investigation.

Our combined assessments indicated that both students and faculty benefitted from participation in these courses. Students demonstrated increased experimental design and data analysis skills, as well as positive attitudes about research and their own scientific skills and retention in STEM-related disciplines. Seventy-nine total students enrolled in at least one of our three research-based courses. Three quarters also participated in a separate independent undergraduate research experiences with nearly one third enrolled students completing an honors thesis. Slightly less than half of the students are pursuing or intend to pursue STEM-related graduate degrees, while slightly more than half are pursuing or intend to pursue training in STEM-related professional schools. As significant broader impacts, 97% of all of the students in each of our three research-intensive courses intend to continue in STEM-related careers. Faculty also benefitted in the form of increased research productivity, increased student participation in our research labs, and increased collaboration.

Overall, our collaborative course design presents a cohesive model of how CUREs involving collaboration among multiple faculty across diverse disciplines and departments can be linked across a university curriculum to provide significant learning and career benefits to a large population of students and faculty at a single institution. Our findings support the assertion that incorporation of faculty research into classroom laboratories helps overcome the limits of time and institutional support for faculty balancing significant research and teaching duties. Based on faculty, student, and scientific outcomes, this collaborative CURE model provides a general outline for bridging faculty teaching and research expectations while maintaining strong student learning outcomes.
